pros: The campus is very pretty and parking is free.
cons: Administrative, financial, and employment practices and policies are non-standard, and not clearly documented. College culture is hypocritical and very status conscious.

pros: This is a good school, regardless of what you study here. The people here are really amazing, including students and professors. Everyone is generally really supportive and friendly.

pros: The students are super nice and polite. The work is easy and coworkers are generally easy to get along with.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Staff is always understanding and will not only allow you to put your education first, but will encourage it.

pros: Generally decent treatment of employees. Good atmosphere.

job_title: Student ITS Associate in Swarthmore, PA
pros: While originally there was little to no organization of the students in the department, and no accountability, a new boss took over the students and drastically improved it. Working at the helpdesk requires real work now, but you can learn a lot and I actually received interview requests from two very large firms that high a lot of Swarthmore alums. Very supportive environment, with a defined schedule but a lot of room for flexibility if you find someone to cover for you.
cons: If you work at the helpdesk, it is very difficult to do homework. While there are fewer of these people now thanks to the new boss, you still get some people who will yell at you for something that someone else did which is unpleasant. Pay is good for work-study, but still very bad compared to what you actually deserve to earn once you've had some experience.

pros: A phonathon caller earns the highest pay grade, works in a fun environment, has the opportunity to earn many bonuses that come in the form of Amazon.com or Swarthmore Bookstore gift cards, and even gets a free dinner and candy while on the job!
cons: Making call after call, day after day, and week after week really wears you down after a while.  I would recommend not working this job more than two or three days a week.  Also, the people you call may not always be polite.  Just keep in mind that their rudeness is not directed so much at you as it is at any of their dissatisfaction at Swarthmore as an institution.

job_title: Student Academic Mentor in Swarthmore, PA
pros:
-Chance to really help students with a range of problems. 
-great leadership experience.
cons:
-pay is terrible-it was arranged as an hourly wage for four hours a week, when it should be either a stipended position or a position where you're actually paid for the hours you work (there were some weeks where I worked 10-20 hours and was paid for four). 
-the SAM directors have no clue what they're doing. 
-If you really want to help students, become an RA instead (or be a SAM for a year as a precursor to being an RA).

job_title: Career Peer Advisor in Swarthmore, PA
pros: Working as a CPA for Swarthmore Career Services is one of the best jobs on campus. Not only do you receive top-notch training on the internship and job search process (how to write and revise a resume and cover letter, networking, interview prep, etc), you also have the opportunity to help other students translate their passions into internship and career opportunities.
cons: It can be a bigger time commitment that you initially anticipate beyond just your 3.5 hour work shift per week because you'll be asked to staff different events and workshops throughout the semester.

review_title: A very eye opening work experience
job_title: Short Order Cook in Swarthmore, PA
pros: Some of the most passionate intellectuals I have ever met gathered together to enact the vision of a school with a history over 200 years old.
cons: Sometimes the atmosphere of the place can be kind of stifling. Additionally, its sometimes difficult to express your dissatisfaction at the new rules coming into place.

review_title: As a former student, working at Swarthmore as a full-time student was tough but necessary and ultimately fulfilling
pros: Salary ranges are very acceptable, often feels like you're getting paid for doing not that much work; takes effort to balance work and academics but it's definitely possible; many different opportunities to earn money while at Swat, whether or not you're on a work study.
cons: It can be difficult to balance a job and academics at Swarthmore; some jobs are more difficult to get as an underclassman;

review_title: Low pay, but I learned a lot.
job_title: Information Technology Student Associate in Swarthmore, PA
pros: The office culture is extremely casual. Very laidback atmosphere. I learned a lot during my time there. Full-time staffers are all extremely approachable.
cons: Student worker pay hasn't increased at all in the past eight years, despite tuition increasing by thousands of dollars. Actual office is dimly lit.

review_title: For students, a great place to work with varied opportunity for advancement
pros:
- Job acquisition is simple; generally one needs only to fill out a few tax forms
- Job diversity is impressive; one can be a librarian assistant, a lifeguard, or a research assistant
- Co-working professionals - academics and administrative - invite relationships and provide excellent career advice
cons: Pay rate max is ~$9/hr for students. That said, students can work, in general, up to 20 hours/week.

pros:
- workload is pretty light
- work's enjoyable--it's fun to teach younger students, and you cement your own knowledge of the material
cons:
- the pay is decent for students, but you can make more doing part time work NOT directly for the school
- job is over at the end of the semester

review_title: The best of times, the worst of times
pros: Great Students, good compensation package, very good academic resources, good work-life balance. The village is quaint and pretty and fairly tranquil, given its proximity to Philadelphia.
cons: Everybody knows everybody, which in such a small place can lead to cliques and ostracizing of non-insiders. This certainly doesn't apply to all faculty and/or staff, but it is an element within the College.

pros: Competitive salaries, extremely generous benefits, and a campus culture that is strongly committed to diversity and inclusion. Strong cultural values.
cons: Not many really. Things move slowly because the college is committed to the practice of concise building, meaning many, many stakeholders from all different levels will be asked to weigh in on decisions. If you're coming from the for-profit world you may struggle with this.

pros:
Your hours are very flexible, but you must be available often to answer emails and handle inquiries.
Get to handle situations with students/professors alike.
Learn about the surrounding area in Swarthmore
cons:
Limited Resources as manager (vans are not the best and students can only work so much)
Sometimes you may have to cover shifts because students can be flaky at times

job_title: Student Academic Mentor in Swarthmore, PA
pros: SAM training was very robust, and the SAM coordinator is great, very flexible, supportive, and easy to work with!
cons: Pay is on the low side for a lot of jobs, and depending on what job you're doing, you can get stuck with some disorganized management or some infelxible admin.

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Swarthmore, PA
pros:
- work with other swarthmore students and professors 
- one of the highest hourly wages on campus
cons: -not very many hours per week - the most I ever had was 5 or 6

review_title: A good introduction to adjusting your daily routine to fit in work.
job_title: Swarthmore McCabe Library Circulation Assistant in Swarthmore, PA
pros: Great, cooperative, friendly people. Able to request subs if you inform the administrators and fellow workers in advance.
cons: Low pay rates for students, compared to other colleges and universities of similar calibre. Schedules often conflict with class schedules etc.

Intelligent, captivating, concerned, invested and knowledgeable professors
concerned administration
resources
location

Able to work multiple jobs and get good flexible hours
Decent amount of autonomy in scheduling depending on the job
cons: Different jobs have different pay grades for students so some students make less than others for the same hours of work

pros: Love it. Really challenging environment, but the professors are super supportive and want you to succeed.
cons: There is a culture of misery and the students compete for who can be more miserable.

pros: Very flexible schedule and great quality of life. Amazing benefits. Awesome 403b retirement package!
cons: Little to no upward mobility. Your job is your job. Salary increases are minimal.
